data.title: List of ancient Greek philosophers
data.meta_description: List of ancient Greek philosophers. GitHub Gist: instantly share code, notes, and snippets.
data.text:
Scientific-rationalist orientation.

Thales

Miletus

ca. 624–-546 BC

Anaximander

Miletus

ca. 610 – 546 BC

Anaximenes

Miletus

ca. 585--528 BC

Anaxagoras

Born in Clazomenae (Ionia), but then went to Athens

ca. 510--428 BC

Introduced philosophy to Athens

Leucippus and Democritus

Miletus (Leucippus), Abdera (Democritus)

Between 500 BC and 400 BC (Leucippus), ca. 460--370 BC (Democritus)

Mystic-religious orientation.

Pythagoras

Croton, Metapontum

ca. 570--495 BC

Xenophanes

Born in Colophon (Ionia), but lived in Magna Graecia

ca. 570--475 BC

Ideas

"Horses would paint the forms of gods like horses"

Criticised Pythagoras, and Homer and Hesiod

Heraclitus

Ephesus

ca. 535--475 BC

Although being from Ionia, he had more a mystic-religious orientation

Parmenides

Elea

ca. 515–-445 BC

Zeno

Elea

ca. 490--430 BC

Empedocles

Acragas

490--430 BC

Ideas

Showed that air is a substance (putting a veseel upside down into water)

Described centrifugal force (whirl a bucket of water around and the wather does not come out)

Four elements earth, air, fire, and water

Dynamic of cosmos is governed by love and repulsion of basic elements

Subjectivist orientation.

Protagoras

Born in Abdera (Thrace), then itinerary in Greece, including Athens

ca. 490–-420 BC

Gorgias

Socrates

Athens

469--399 BC

Plato

Aristotle

At beginning materialistic (i.e. no immortality of soul), later immaterialistic. Developed from Cynicism. Early stoics where Syrians, later ones Romans.

Zeno

Cleanthes

Chrysippus

Panaetius

Posidonius

Seneca

Epictetus

Marcus Aurelius

Main competitior of Stoicism. Survived until 5th century AD, then disappeared in favour of Neoplatonism (educated minority) and Christianity (uneducated majority).

Epicurus

Lucretius

Plato's Academy became sceptical with Arcesilaus for 200 years. Then it became stoic.

Pyrrho

Timon

Arcesilaus

Carneades

Clitomachus

Cynicism started with Antisthenes, who lived at the same time as Plato and Aristotle.

Antisthenes

Diogenes

Crates

Teles
